questions.text: Which of the following statements about the pancreatic islets is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: A-cells are the most prevalent and primarily secrete insulin.

options.label: B
options.text: B cells constituting 60–75% of islet cells primarily secrete glucagon

options.label: C
options.text: F cells, which are the most abundant, primarily secrete pancreatic polypeptide.

options.label: D
options.text: B cells are the most prevalent and secrete insulin.

questions.correct_answer: D. B cells are the most prevalent and secrete insulin.
questions.explanation:
Cell Type

Percentage of Islet Cells

Location

Hormone Secreted

Hormone Function

B cells

60-75%

Center

Insulin (Option B)

Lowers blood glucose

A cell (Option A)

20%

Surround B cells

Glucagon

Increases blood glucose

D cells

Less common

Encircle B cells

Somatostatin

Regulates islet cell secretion

F cells

Less common (Option C)

Encircle B cells

Pancreatic polypeptide

Regulates ion transport in the intestine

questions.text: Which conditions would most likely result in a high insulin-glucagon molar (I/G ratio)?

options.label: A
options.text: Prolonged fasting

options.label: B
options.text: Adopting a low-carbohydrate diet

options.label: C
options.text: Starvation

options.label: D
options.text: Consumption of a large carbohydrate meal

questions.correct_answer: D. Consumption of a large carbohydrate meal
questions.explanation:
Insulin Glucagon Ratio

Condition

Hepatic Glucose Storage/ Production

I/G Ratio

Features

Large Carbohydrate Meal

Storage

70
  • Indicates energy abundance
  • Promotes glycogenesis, lipogenesis, and protein synthesis

IV Glucose

Storage

25

Small Meal

Storage

7

Overnight Fasting

Production

2.3
  • Indicates the need to mobilise energy stores
  • Promotes glycogenolysis, gluconeogenesis, and ketogenesis

Low Carbohydrate Diet

Production

1.8

Starvation

Production

0.4

questions.text: Which of the following actions is NOT a physiological effect of glucagon?

options.label: A
options.text: Stimulating glycogen synthesis in the liver

options.label: B
options.text: Promoting gluconeogenesis

options.label: C
options.text: Increasing glycogen breakdown in the liver

options.label: D
options.text: Enhancing lipolysis in the liver

questions.correct_answer: A. Stimulating glycogen synthesis in the liver
questions.explanation:
Glucagon

Stimulators

Inhibitors
  • Amino acids (alanine, arginine)
  • Cortisol
  • Exercise
  • Infections
  • High blood glucose levels
  • Somatostatin
  • Insulin
  • Free fatty acids and ketones

questions.text: Which of the following does not stimulate insulin secretion?

options.label: A
options.text: α-Adrenergic receptor activation

options.label: B
options.text: Activation of parasympathetic nerves

options.label: C
options.text: Stimulation of β-Adrenergic receptors

options.label: D
options.text: Release of GLP-1

questions.correct_answer: A. α-Adrenergic receptor activation
questions.explanation:
INSULIN

Stimulators of Insulin Release

Inhibitors of Insulin Release
  • Glucose
  • Amino acids (e.g., arginine, lysine)
  • Gastrointestinal hormones (e.g., GLP-1, GIP)
  • Parasympathetic stimulation (via acetylcholine)
  • β-Adrenergic receptor activation
  • Sulfonylurea drugs
  • Low Blood Glucose
  • Somatostatin
  • α-Adrenergic receptor activation
  • Leptin
  • Galanin

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the mechanisms of action of oral hypoglycemic drugs is FALSE?

options.label: A
options.text: GLP-1 analogues enhance insulin release only at high glucose concentrations and reduce glucagon release

options.label: B
options.text: Sulfonylureas bind to the sulfonylurea receptor (SUR1) on pancreatic β-cells, stimulating insulin secretion even at low glucose concentrations.

options.label: C
options.text: GLP-1 analogues increase gastric emptying by stimulating specific GLP-1 receptors.

options.label: D
options.text: DPP-4 inhibitors increase endogenous GLP-1 levels by preventing its degradation.

questions.correct_answer: C. GLP-1 analogues increase gastric emptying by stimulating specific GLP-1 receptors.
questions.explanation:
ORAL HYPOGLYCEMIC DRUGS

Sulphonylureas

(Option B)

Mechanism of action: Sulfonylureas bind to the sulfonylurea receptor (SUR1) on the membrane of pancreatic β-cells, which stimulates insulin secretion regardless of glucose concentration.

 

This results in a significant and often unregulated release of insulin, potentially leading to severe hypoglycemia, especially at low glucose levels.

 

Examples: Tolbutamide, Glipizide, Glibenclamide.

GLP-1 Analogues

(Option A)

Mechanism of Action: GLP-1 analogues activate GLP-1 receptors, which are GPCRs located on pancreatic β-cells, α-cells, central and peripheral neurons, and gastrointestinal mucosa.

 

This activation promotes insulin secretion specifically in response to high glucose levels, inhibits glucagon release, slows gastric emptying, and suppresses appetite.

 

GLP-1 analogues also contribute to pancreatic β-cell health by reducing islet cell apoptosis.

 

Examples: Exenatide, Liraglutide.

DPP-4 Inhibitors

(Option D)

Mechanism of Action: DPP-4 inhibitors block the enzyme DPP-4, which normally breaks down endogenous GLP-1. By inhibiting this enzyme, these drugs increase the levels of GLP-1, thereby enhancing insulin secretion indirectly and improving glycemic control.

 

Examples: Sitagliptin, Saxagliptin, Vildagliptin.

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism by which glucose stimulates insulin secretion in pancreatic β-cells?

options.label: A
options.text: Glucose stimulates insulin release directly by binding to its receptor on β-cells, triggering immediate secretion.

options.label: B
options.text: Glucose is metabolized to pyruvate, increasing ATP, which inhibits ATP-sensitive K+ channels, causing Ca2+ influx and insulin release.

options.label: C
options.text: Glucose lowers intracellular glutamate, promoting insulin secretion by altering pH in secretory granules and affecting their release.

options.label: D
options.text: Glucose enhances the uptake of calcium into the β-cells without affecting ATP levels, thereby directly increasing the secretion of insulin.

questions.correct_answer: B. Glucose is metabolized to pyruvate, increasing ATP, which inhibits ATP-sensitive K+ channels, causing Ca2+ influx and insulin release.
questions.explanation:
Biphasic response of Insulin secretion

First Rapid Phase

Second Prolonged Phase
  • Glucose enters pancreatic β-cells via GLUT-2 transporters.
  • Inside the cell, glucose is phosphorylated by glucokinase and converted to pyruvate.
  • Pyruvate is metabolized in the mitochondria, producing ATP. (Option D)
  • Increased ATP inhibits ATP-sensitive K+ channels, leading to reduced K+ efflux.
  • This depolarizes the β-cell membrane, causing voltage-gated Ca2+ channels to open.
  • Ca2+ influx triggers the exocytosis of a pool of insulin-containing granules,
  • Results in a rapid, short-lived increase in insulin secretion.
  • Peak within 1–2 minutes and then decreases to basal level in another 2 to 3 minutes
  • Pyruvate metabolism increases intracellular glutamate levels. (Option C)
  • Glutamate acts as an intracellular second messenger, priming a second pool of secretory granules for release.
  • It may also lower the pH in granules, aiding in their maturation.
  • This leads to a prolonged phase of insulin secretion.
  • Peak in about 60 minutes and then remain elevated for 3–5 hours.

questions.text: Match the following actions of insulin with the correct category: Categories: a) Increased by insulin b) Decreased by insulin Insulin Action: Cell growth Reabsorption of K+, Na+, and phosphate from the kidney Food intake Entry of phosphate and magnesium into the cell Body weight Lipolysis Potassium uptake into cells

Which of the following are the actions of insulin? 1) Increased lipogenesis 2) Increased ketogenesis 3) Increased glycogen synthesis 4) Increased glucose uptake 5) Increased gluconeogenesis 6) Increased protein synthesis

A medical student curious about the physiological effects of insulin learns that insulin has rapid, intermediate, and delayed actions on various metabolic processes. Which of the following is an intermediate action of insulin?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased transport of K+ into insulin-sensitive cells

options.label: B
options.text: Stimulation of protein synthesis

options.label: C
options.text: Increase in mRNAs for lipogenic enzymes

options.label: D
options.text: Increased transport of amino acids into insulin-sensitive cells

questions.correct_answer: B. Stimulation of protein synthesis
questions.explanation:
PRINCIPAL ACTIONS OF INSULIN

Rapid (seconds)
  • Increased transport of
    • Glucose,
    • Amino acids (Option D)
    • K+ (Option A)

into insulin-sensitive cells

Intermediate (minutes)
  • Stimulation of protein synthesis
  • Inhibition of protein degradation
  • Activation of glycolytic enzymes and glycogen synthase
  • Inhibition of phosphorylase and gluconeogenic enzymes

Delayed (hours)
  • Increase in mRNAs for lipogenic and other enzymes (Option C)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about insulin receptors, GLUT, and SGLT is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: The insulin receptor's β subunits are responsible for insulin binding.

options.label: B
options.text: GLUT-4 transporters increase glucose uptake in response to insulin.

options.label: C
options.text: SGLT transporters primarily function in muscle and adipose tissue.

options.label: D
options.text: SGLT-2 inhibitors work by increasing glucose absorption in the kidneys.

questions.correct_answer: B. GLUT-4 transporters increase glucose uptake in response to insulin.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about insulin synthesis is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Insulin synthesis begins in the Golgi apparatus with the formation of proinsulin.

options.label: B
options.text: The C peptide is removed during the conversion of preproinsulin to proinsulin.

options.label: C
options.text: The insulin gene is located on the long arm of chromosome 11.

options.label: D
options.text: Insulin and C peptides are released from B cells in equimolar amounts.

questions.correct_answer: D. Insulin and C peptides are released from B cells in equimolar amounts.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a painless, enlarging neck mass. Ultrasound reveals multiple thyroid nodules. Which of the following histological findings is most consistent with an inactive thyroid gland?

options.label: A
options.text: Small follicles with cuboidal cells and minimal colloid

options.label: B
options.text: Large follicles with abundant colloid

options.label: C
options.text: Numerous granular endoplasmic reticulum, lysosomes, and Golgi complexes

options.label: D
options.text: Parafollicular cells secreting calcitonin

questions.correct_answer: B. Large follicles with abundant colloid
questions.explanation:
Follicular cells

Parafollicular cells
  • The Apical Membrane of follicular cells faces the colloid and is covered with microvilli.
  • The cytoplasm contains numerous granular endoplasmic reticulum, lysosomes, and Golgi complexes.
  • Also known as C cells
  • Located close to the follicles.
  • Basal Membrane is in close contact with numerous capillaries in the interfollicular space.
  • Secrete calcitonin.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the treatment of thyroid disorders is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Propylthiouracil is used to treat hypothyroidism.

options.label: B
options.text: Radioactive iodine therapy is used for the treatment of Graves disease.

options.label: C
options.text: Levothyroxine helps treat hyperthyroidism.

options.label: D
options.text: Hashimoto thyroiditis causes a long-term increase in thyroid hormone production.

questions.correct_answer: B. Radioactive iodine therapy is used for the treatment of Graves disease.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Hypothyroidism

Hyperthyroidism

Causes

Iodine deficiency, Hashimoto thyroiditis, pituitary/hypothalamic failure, drug-induced

Graves disease, toxic adenoma, early Hashimoto thyroiditis, TSH-secreting tumor

Symptoms

Mental and physical slowing, cold intolerance, weight gain, dry/yellowish skin, constipation, hair loss

Nervousness, weight loss, heat intolerance, tachycardia, tremor, exophthalmos

Treatment

Levothyroxine, iodine supplementation, hormone replacement therapy, medication adjustments

Antithyroid medications, radioactive iodine therapy, surgery

questions.text: What is the primary metabolic consequence of fasting on thyroid hormone levels?

options.label: A
options.text: ↑T4 to T3 conversion, hence ↑ T3

options.label: B
options.text: ↓T4 to T3 conversion, ↓plasma T3 levels, and ↑ RT3 levels.

options.label: C
options.text: ↓T3 and normal RT3.

options.label: D
options.text: ↑ BMR

questions.correct_answer: B. ↓T4 to T3 conversion, ↓plasma T3 levels, and ↑ RT3 levels.

questions.text: A 28 y/o woman visits her physician with complaints of weight loss, increased appetite, and anxiety. She feels warmer than usual and has noticed an increased frequency of bowel movements.O/E, her heart rate is elevated, and lab tests reveal elevated levels of thyroid hormones. Which of the following best describes the effects of thyroid hormones on metabolism in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Decrease oxygen consumption and promote energy storage in tissues.

options.label: B
options.text: Stimulate lipogenesis and reduce the turnover of glucose in the body.

options.label: C
options.text: Increase the rate of glucose absorption & lipid oxidation

options.label: D
options.text: Inhibit proteolysis, thereby conserving muscle mass and reducing metabolic activity.

questions.correct_answer: C. Increase the rate of glucose absorption & lipid oxidation
questions.explanation:
Carbohydrate Metabolism
  • Increase absorption of glucose from the intestine.
  • Induce hepatic gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis, raising plasma glucose.
  • Increase glucose turnover by enhancing its uptake and oxidation. (Option B)

Fat Metabolism

  • Stimulate lipolysis, releasing free fatty acids and glycerol.
  • Increase lipid turnover and facilitate oxidation.
  • Stimulate cholesterol synthesis, oxidation, and biliary excretion.
  • Enhance hepatic uptake of cholesterol by increasing LDL receptor expression.
  • Net effect: a significant decrease in plasma cholesterol and total lipid levels.

Protein metabolism

(Option D)
  • Promote proteolysis in skeletal muscle, releasing amino acids.
  • Increase protein turnover by enhancing protein degradation.

Heart Rate and Cardiac Output
  • Increase the heart rate by upregulating and sensitizing β-receptors in the SA and AV nodes, leading to tachycardia in hyperthyroidism.
  • Enhance myocardial contractility by increasing stroke volume hence increasing cardiac output (CO).

Blood Pressure
  • Systolic blood pressure: ↥heart rate and stroke volume results in increased CO
  • Diastolic pressure: decreases due to calorigenic-induced thermogenic cutaneous vasodilation, resulting in decreased peripheral resistance.
  • The overall effect is an increased pulse pressure, which is prominent in hyperthyroidism.

Circulation Dynamics
  • Enhanced cardiac output and vasodilation create hyperdynamic circulation, leading to shortened circulation time.

Target system

Functions

CNS
  • Important for the maturation of CNS especially during infancy and childhood
  • Essential for overall brain functions including memory, learning, alertness, and reflexes.
  • Lack of thyroid hormones during infancy can cause irreversible CNS development retardation.

Skeletal muscle
  • Thyroid hormones increase MHC gene expression in skeletal muscle, leading to muscle cramps and weakness in hypothyroidism.
  • Hyperthyroidism also causes muscle weakness due to increased protein catabolism, with chronic cases resulting in thyrotoxic myopathy.

Bones
  • It is essential for normal growth, and musculoskeletal maturation, and promotes the expression of growth hormone (GH) genes.
  • Increase osteoid activity, bone growth, and bone remodeling, and promote the growth of teeth, epidermis, nails, and hair.
  • In hypothyroid children, bone growth slows, and epiphyseal closure is delayed.

GIT
  • Stimulates GI motility, ↑ appetite, ↑ Carbohydrate absorption

Reproduction
  • Follicular maturation and ovulation

Respiration
  • During hypercapnia & hypoxia, they increase oxygen consumption in tissues by : (Option A)
    • ↑ RR
    • ↑ arterial PO2
    • ↑ erythropoietin synthesis

questions.text: A 35 y/o male presents with symptoms of lethargy, hair loss, and cold intolerance. His lab results show elevated T4 levels but low T3 levels. Which of the following best explains the relationship between T4 and T3 in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: T4 is the primary thyroid hormone and is converted to the more active T3 in peripheral tissues.

options.label: B
options.text: T3 has a longer half-life than T4, allowing it to maintain steady levels in the bloodstream.

options.label: C
options.text: Elevated T4 levels automatically indicate that T3 levels should also be elevated, due to their synchronous production.

options.label: D
options.text: T4 is biologically active, while T3 is inactive and serves primarily as a storage form of thyroid hormone.

questions.correct_answer: A. T4 is the primary thyroid hormone and is converted to the more active T3 in peripheral tissues.
questions.explanation:
Difference between T4 & T3

Aspect

T4

T3

Secretion

More (35% of total)

Less (7% of total)

Plasma conc.

8 mg/dL

0.15 mg/dL

Protein-bound

99.8%

99.8%

Free concentration in plasma

2 ng/dL

0.3 ng/dL

Half-life (t1/2)

(Option B)

7 days

1 day

Action

Slower

Faster

Potency

Less

More (3-5 times)

Binding to thyroid hormone receptors

Low affinity

High affinity

questions.text: A 50 y/o male presents with fatigue, weight gain, and feeling cold. Blood tests show normal T4, low T3, and elevated RT3 levels. Which of the following best explains the patient's symptoms and lab findings?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased activity of 5´-deiodinase in the liver and kidney

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased activity of 5-deiodinase

options.label: C
options.text: Increased activity of 5-deiodinase

options.label: D
options.text: Reduced secretion of thyroxine (T4) from the thyroid gland

questions.correct_answer: C. Increased activity of 5-deiodinase
questions.explanation:
Conversion to T3
  • 35% of secreted T4 is converted to T3 in the circulation by the enzyme 5'-deiodinase, mainly found in the liver and kidneys.
 
  • This process produces about 85% of circulating T3, the most active hormone that primarily affects target cells.

Conversion to RT3
  • 45% of T4 is also converted to reverse T3 (RT3) by the enzyme 5-deiodinase.
  • RT3 is physiologically inert and accounts for 95% of circulating RT3.

Type of deiodinase

Location

Function

D1
  • Liver
  • Kidney
  • Thyroid
  • Pituitary
  • Function as 5´-deiodinases, converting thyroxine (T4) to triiodothyronine (T3)
  • Maintaining intracellular T3 levels in target tissues

D2
  • Skeletal muscle
  • Brain
  • Pituitary
  • Placenta
  • Brown fat
  • Its function is the same as D1
  • It maintains a steady supply of T3 to neurons in the brain.

D3
  • Brain
  • Reproductive tissue
  • Converts T4 to reverse T3 (RT3), a biologically inactive form.

questions.text: A 30y/o pregnant woman has elevated thyroid-binding globulin (TBG) but shows no symptoms of thyroid dysfunction. Her endocrinologist explains this is common during pregnancy and that her thyroid function remains normal. Which of the following best explains why the pregnant woman is experiencing this?

options.label: A
options.text: TSH secretion is decreased due to elevated TBG levels

options.label: B
options.text: Elevated TBG levels reduce the production of thyroid hormones

options.label: C
options.text: A temporary fall in free thyroid hormones stimulates TSH secretion, restoring equilibrium

options.label: D
options.text: Increased TBG levels compensate for the reduced free hormone levels by decreasing the metabolic clearance rate of thyroid hormones

questions.correct_answer: C. A temporary fall in free thyroid hormones stimulates TSH secretion, restoring equilibrium

questions.text: A 38y/o woman presents with symptoms of fatigue, weight gain, and dry skin. Laboratory tests reveal low free T4 and elevated TSH levels. Further investigation shows increased levels of thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG). Which of the following is most likely to be associated with increased levels of thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG)

options.label: A
options.text: Phenytoin

options.label: B
options.text: Androgens

options.label: C
options.text: Glucocorticoids

options.label: D
options.text: Estrogen

questions.correct_answer: D. Estrogen
questions.explanation:
Thyroxine Binding Globulin (TBG)
  • Nature: Glycoprotein synthesized by the liver with a molecular weight of 54,000.
  • Binding Capacity: Each TBG molecule has a single binding site for thyroid hormones.
  • Binding Proportion: About 70% of T4 and 45% of T3 bind to TBG.
  • Plasma Level Influences:
    Increase: During pregnancy and in patients receiving estrogen, major tranquilizers, and clofibrate.
  • Decrease: In patients receiving glucocorticoids, androgens, danazol, L-asparaginase, salicylates, phenytoin, mitotane, and 5-fluorouracil (Option A, B, C)

Thyroxine Binding Prealbumin (TBPA) /Transthyretin
  • Nature: A globulin, not an albumin, recently designated as transthyretin.
  • Binding Proportion:
    T3: Less than 1% binds to TBPA.
    T4: About 20% binds to TBPA.

Albumin
  • Binding Proportion:
    T3: About 55% binds to albumin.
    T4: About 10% binds to albumin.

questions.text: A patient with a history of Graves' disease is treated with a high dose of iodide. Initially, there is a reduction in thyroid hormone synthesis due to the Wolff-Chaikoff effect. However, after a few days, the patient's thyroid function returns to normal. Which of the following mechanisms explains this "escape" phenomenon?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased degradation of thyroglobulin

options.label: B
options.text: Upregulation of the sodium-iodide symporter (NIS)

options.label: C
options.text: Downregulation of the sodium-iodide symporter (NIS)

options.label: D
options.text: Increased conversion of T4 to T3 in peripheral tissues

questions.correct_answer: C. Downregulation of the sodium-iodide symporter (NIS)
questions.explanation:
Mechanism:
  • Inhibition of Organic Binding: Large doses of iodide inhibit the organic binding of iodide within the thyroid gland, reducing hormone synthesis.

TSH Effect Inhibition:
  • High iodide levels decrease cAMP production in thyroid cells, inhibiting the effect of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH). (Wolff-Chaikoff effect)
  • This reduces the proteolysis of thyroglobulin, further decreasing hormone synthesis.
 

Purpose
  • The Wolff-Chaikoff effect serves to prevent the thyroid from synthesizing excessive amounts of thyroid hormones in the presence of large quantities of iodide.

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of hypothyroidism despite adequate iodine intake. Upon investigation, it is found that there is a defect in the enzyme responsible for a key step in thyroid hormone synthesis. Which of the following steps in thyroid hormone synthesis is not facilitated by thyroid peroxidase (TPO)?

options.label: A
options.text: Oxidation of iodide to iodine

options.label: B
options.text: Coupling of iodotyrosines

options.label: C
options.text: Iodide trapping

options.label: D
options.text: Binding of iodine to thyroglobulin

questions.correct_answer: C. Iodide trapping
questions.explanation:
1. Iodide Trapping
  • Mechanism: Iodide is actively transported into thyroid follicles (iodide pump).
  • Process: Na+ and I⁻ co-transported into the cell by Na+-I⁻ symporter (NIS).TSH induces expression and retention of NIS.
  • Na+ is pumped out by the Na+-K+ pump.
  • Iodide is pumped against electrical and chemical gradients using ATP.
  • Other Tissues: Salivary glands, placenta, choroid plexus, mammary gland, gastric mucosa, and ciliary body also accumulate iodide but do not form thyroid hormones.
  • Iodide trapping is stimulated by TSH.

2. Conversion of Iodide into Iodine
  • Process: Iodide is converted to iodine by oxidation.
  • Oxidation (organification) facilitated by thyroid peroxidase. (Option A)

3. Thyroglobulin Synthesis
  • Thyroglobulin: Glycoprotein with two subunits and 123 tyrosine residues.
  • Synthesis: Synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum of thyroid cells.
  • Packaged in Golgi apparatus and secreted into colloid by exocytosis.
  • Facilitated by thyroid peroxidase. (Option D)
  • Binding: Reactive iodine binds to tyrosine on thyroglobulin, forming monoiodotyrosine (MIT) and diiodotyrosine (DIT).

4. The Coupling Reaction
  • Formation: Two DIT molecules condense to form thyroxine (T4).
  • MIT and DIT condense to form triiodothyronine (T3).
  • Reverse-T3 (RT3) formed by condensation of DIT with MIT.
  • Mechanism: Intramolecular coupling (both DIT attached to thyroglobulin).
  • Intermolecular coupling (DIT detached from thyroglobulin).
  • Facilitation: Coupling reaction facilitated by thyroid peroxidase (Option B).

5. Proteolysis of Thyroglobulin
  • Process: Colloid ingested by thyroid cells via endocytosis.
  • Lysosomal enzymes digest peptide bonds in thyroglobulin.
  • Free T4, T3, DIT, and MIT formed in the cytoplasm.
  • Iodotyrosine deiodinase deiodinates MIT and DIT.
  • T3 and T4 are released into circulation.
  • Iodine from deiodination is reutilized by the gland.

6. Secretion of Thyroid Hormones
  • Release: T3 and T4 are secreted into general circulation.
  • MIT and DIT are not secreted by the thyroid gland.
